bibl.title: Letter from Isador W. Mendelsohn to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1922

div1.p: Mendelsohn discusses problems surrounding the publication of Carter's article on malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Isador W. Mendelsohn to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1922
div1.opener:
N. Mal C,
Abstract
OFFICE OF THE DISTRICT ENGINEER
Butler Building,
Washington, D.C.
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
May 20, 1922.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Dr. Carter:-
div1.p:
I wish to acknowledge receipt of your recent communication and appre-
ciate your giving me the opportunity of reading Mr. Bair's communication
on Public Health Engineering Abstracts. The malaria abstract that you
refer to has been in Miss Vaughan's file for the past three months, in
view of her illness and absence from the office. I have not included this
abstract in Public Health Engineering Abstracts in view of the fact that
it has not been typrewritten and also in view of the fact that the abstract
was taken up by you with Miss Vaughan so that no one but she could type-
write the abstract. As soon as she returns, I will have the abstract in-
cluded in Public Health Engineering Abstracts.
I am returning Mr. Bair's letter.

We all hope that your recent physical ailment has been corrected at
John Hopkins Hospital and that you will be about with your usual energy in
a short time.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, Isador W. Mendelsohn,
Assistant Sanitary Engineer. O'N
Encl.
